meanings.definition: Reversion of property to the state when the owner dies without heirs.
meanings.sent1: When the old man passed away with no family, the house escheats to the government.
meanings.sent2: In history class, we learned about escheats and how they occur when someone has no heirs.
meanings.sent3: The story of the lonely king who left behind a kingdom that escheated to the kingdom next door was quite a tale.
meanings.sent4: The abandoned mansion stood as a silent reminder of the escheat that took place after the last heir vanished.
meanings.sent5: The concept of escheats can be confusing, but it basically means the state gets the property if no one else can inherit it.

meanings.definition: To revert to the state as an escheat.
meanings.sent1: If the owner doesn't have any heirs, the property escheats to the government.
meanings.sent2: When a person passes away without leaving a will, their estate escheats according to the law.
meanings.sent3: The old car, forgotten in the garage, seemed to escheat to nature as vines started growing around it.
meanings.sent4: Time seemed to escheat the memories of the town's founding, leaving only faint traces of the past.
meanings.sent5: The abandoned building slowly escheated into disrepair, becoming a shadow of its former self.

meanings.definition: The right of the state to take possession of property when the owner dies without heirs.
meanings.sent1: The law grants the government the escheats to unclaimed property in certain situations.
meanings.sent2: Escheats ensure that assets do not remain in limbo when there are no rightful heirs.
meanings.sent3: The comedy sketch about the state's right to escheat property had the audience in stitches.
meanings.sent4: In the game of Monopoly, players can experience the power of escheats when landing on unclaimed properties.
meanings.sent5: The concept of escheats serves as a safety net to prevent property from being ownerless and unused.
